  • [Researcher]

    Oct 2019 > Jun 2023 (3 years and 9 months)

    PhD | Human Computer Interaction

    ISIR Laboratory, Sorbonne Université

    From 2019 to 2023, I worked on a PhD thesis in the field of Human Computer Interaction at the ISIR laboratory (HCI group) at Sorbonne University in Paris.

    I was supervised by Yvonne Jansen and Gilles Bailly, to work on the design of tools to support knowledge sharing related to fabrication activities inside makerspaces, fablabs, workshops, and more generally the DIY community.

    My thesis is part of the AfFABle project and I worked in close relationship with the Sorbonne University Fablab where I organised weekly workshops arounds different machines, prototyping, programming and crafting activities.

    I defended my thesis on June 15th 2023, and you can watch the full presentation (in French) on Youtube and read the manuscript (in English) here.

  • [Intern]

    Feb 2019 > Aug 2019 (7 months)

    Internship | Robotic Interface and Virtual Reality

    ISIR Laboratory

    At the end of my second year of master’s, I did an internship in the Interaction Team of the ISIR laboratory under the supervision of Gilles Bailly. I was working on the COVR project, which consists of a large virtual reality arena made up of a 2-axis robotic column designed to provide haptic feedback in Virtual Reality.

    During this placement, I worked on the following points:

    • Creating virtual scenes with Unity
    • Building a calibration tool inside Unity to align the coordinates of the VR headset with the coordinates of the motorised column
    • Rendering the user’s real hand in the virtual environment with RGBD-based hand recognition (OpenCV).

    That was at this moment that I realised that HCI would be my thing.

  • [Intern]

    May 2018 > Aug 2018 (4 months)

    Internship | Robotic vision based navigation

    LIP6 Paris

    At the end of the first year of my Master’s degree, I did a placement at the Lip6 laboratory under the supervision of Cédric Herpson. The goal was to perform robotic navigation based solely on visual information and known environment artifacts. To do that, we conceived an algorithm capable of constructing a 3D representation of the walls of the environment in real time, during exploration of a room by the robot. The approach was to use OpenCV to detect key features in the acquired image stream, combined with object detection as a means of acquiring information about the distances of the walls in the room. I didn’t regret not seeing the see that summer!

  • [Intern]

    Jun 2016 > Jul 2016 (2 months)

    Internship | Developping a library for Tangible Spherical Display

    Inria Bordeaux

    For two months, I worked with the MANAO team and the POTIOC team in the INRIA Bordeaux laboratory, under the direction of Patrick Reuter and Anke Brock. I was in charge of designing a JS library for web developers to help them program applications on a spherical touch screen as they would with a traditional 2D web page.

    This work consisted of

    • 1) translating tactile inputs detected on the spherical screen via TUIO into classic JS-like events, including parametric transformations from azimuthal to cylindrical projections coordinates, and
    • 2) applying the inverse visual transformation to DOM elements created in 2D, on the spherical screen.

    My contribution was part of “Code The Globe”, published at the PerDIS conference in 2017.
